channel.title: NYT > Global Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Senators Set to Unveil Immigration Bill
item.description: After tough negotiations, a bipartisan group of eight senators plans to introduce a proposal on Tuesday that contains a 13-year pathway to citizenship for those here illegally.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON

item.title: Europe Rejects Bid to Raise Cost of Carbon Emissions
item.description: The parliamentary vote places the future of the European Union’s flagship effort to combat climate change in doubt.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Strikes in Iran
item.description: An earthquake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale struck near Iran’s border with Pakistan and tremors were felt as far away as India and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: People evacuated buildings in Karachi, Pakistan, after feeling an earthquake that struck with an epicenter in Khash, Iran.

item.title: Downtown Boston Remains Crime Scene
item.description: The day after two bombs exploded near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing three people and injuring more than 140, no arrests had been made.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
item.media:credit: John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An injured woman is tended to at the scene of the first explosion Monday, on Boylston Street near the finish line of the Boston Marathon.

item.title: I.M.F. Lowers Estimates for Global Growth for 2013
item.description: The fund projects worldwide growth of about 3.3 percent this year and 4 percent in 2014; that is a reduction of 0.2 percentage points since January for this year’s figures, and is unchanged for 2014.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY

item.title: Pakistan’s Musharraf Disqualified From Election
item.description: Pakistani judges have disqualified the country’s former military ruler, Pervez Musharraf, from running in the upcoming parliamentary election, lawyers said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Strong Earthquake Is Felt Across Wide Area of Asia
item.description: A powerful earthquake struck Pakistan’s border with Iran, with tremors felt as far away as India and the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: China Suggests U.S. Is Stirring Tensions in Asia
item.description: A defense paper released Tuesday said Washington’s move to strengthen its military presence in Asia and cement ties with allies was a threat to China.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: France Finds Horse Meat in 1 of 8 Samples Tested
item.description: France found more cases of illegal horse meat in beef products than any other European Union country, early results of DNA tests showed.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Practiced Torture After 9/11, Nonpartisan Review Concludes
item.description: The report said the use of torture had “no justification,” “damaged the standing of our nation” and “potentially increased the danger to U.S. military personnel.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Alaska-Based Soldier Gets 16 Years in Spy Case
item.description: An Alaska-based military policeman will serve 16 years in prison and will be dishonorably discharged for selling secrets to an FBI undercover agent who he believed was a Russian spy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Points Finger at U.S. Over Asia-Pacific Tensions
item.description: China’s defense ministry made a thinly veiled attack on the United States on Tuesday for increasing tensions in the Asia-Pacific by ramping up its military presence and alliances in the region.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 2 Blasts at Boston Marathon Kill At Least 3 and Injure More Than 100
item.description: Two bombs exploded seconds apart near the finish line at the Boston Marathon on Monday, creating a bloody, chaotic scene more than four hours into the race.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN ELIGON and MICHAEL COOPER
item.media:credit: Kenshin Okubo/The Daily Free Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pandemonium erupted as runners and spectators scattered after the blasts.

item.title: Senate Immigration Overhaul Likely to Set Off Fight
item.description: Legislation by a bipartisan group of senators, set for introduction on Tuesday, would demand tough border controls but provide a 13-year path to citizenship for certain illegal immigrants.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Charles E. Schumer, left, and John McCain are in a bipartisan group of senators that has drafted major immigration legislation, largely in secret.

item.title: The Lede: Live Updates on the Explosions
item.description: Police say no suspects are in custody; toll rises to two dead, 64 wounded.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Witnesses Describe Scene After Blasts at Boston Marathon
item.description: Witnesses said that the finish line, normally a festive site of celebration and exhaustion, suddenly felt like a battlefield.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ROHAN
item.media:credit: John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An injured woman is tended to at the scene of the first explosion Monday, on Boylston Street near the finish line of the Boston Marathon.

item.title: DealBook: Price of Gold Takes a Flashy Fall; Other Markets Follow
item.description: Gold prices tumbled 9 percent on Monday, the sharpest drop in 30 years, as stocks and other commodities also felt the impact of a disappointing report on Chinese growth.
item.dc:creator: By NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Trial of German Neo-Nazi Is Delayed Over Media Concerns
item.description: A state court delayed the trial of Beate Zschäpe after weeks of outrage over how seats for members of the foreign news media were allocated.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Memo From Spain: Open Season on Spain’s Royal Family
item.description: No longer treated with profound deference, King Juan Carlos and the rest of the monarchy are under scrutiny, and some residents are even calling for an elected head of state.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: King Juan Carlos, left, Queen Sofia and Crown Prince Felipe no longer command the deference they previously enjoyed.

item.title: Tensions High, Obama Agrees to Meet With Putin
item.description: The visit between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin is to be before a Group of 20 conference this fall, but it was being arranged at an awkward time.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Buenos Aires Journal: Buenos Aires’s Historic Heritage Slips Away
item.description: Preservationists say illegal demolitions, chronic underinvestment and unimaginative architecture threaten to erase the city’s history.
item.dc:creator: By EMILY SCHMALL
item.media:credit: Anibal Greco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Passengers on a La Brugeoise train in Buenos Aires. The retirement of the antique wooden train cars prompted local protests.

item.title: Lens Blog: Across Syria, Prize-Winning Pictures of War
item.description: Photographers for the Associated Press and Agence France-Presse won the 2013 Pulitzers for breaking news and feature photography.
item.dc:creator: By JESSE NEWMAN and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: U.S. Sting That Snared Guinea-Bissau Ex-Admiral Shines Light on Drug Trade
item.description: The former chief of the Guinea-Bissau Navy, who was labeled a “drug kingpin” by American officials, faced trafficking charges Monday after a D.E.A. sting.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Rear Adm. José Américo Bubo Na Tchuto, seen here in 2008, was in a New York court Monday.

item.title: Europe Split Over Austerity as a Path to Growth
item.description: Europe is divided over the road to recovery: Is strict belt-tightening or an easing of monetary policy and some stimulus best? The tension in that question will be on full display in Washington this week.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Christine Lagarde, the head of the I.M.F., with Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany’s finance minister and a supporter of austerity.

item.title: India, Known for Outsourcing, Now Wants to Make Its Own Chips
item.description: The Indian government has committed itself to buying half of its computing needs from domestic sources — though India manufactures few of those products.
item.dc:creator: By SEAN McLAIN
item.media:description: Dell computers at a plant in the state of Tamil Nadu. Dell assembles products in India, but does not make components there.
